headline: Ford knew about dangerous backup camera glitches but moved too slowly to fix them, safety regulator says
summary: Ford is being fined up to $165 million after the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration ruled the company moved too slowly in recalling cars with faulty rearview cameras.

headline: What's Going On With Ford Motor Stock Today?
summary: Ford Motor Company (NYSE:F) shares are trading slightly higher on Thursday. Today, the company has agreed to a consent order with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), including a civil penalty of $165 million for failing to meet federal recall requirements. This marks the second-largest civil penalty in NHTSA’s history, following the Takata airbag scandal. headline: Ford agrees to pay up to $165 million penalty to US government for moving too slowly on a recall
summary: Ford Motor Co. will pay a penalty of up to $165 million to the U.S. government for moving too slowly on a recall and failing to give accurate recall information.  The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Thursday that the civil penalty is the second-largest in its 54-year history.  The agency said Ford was too slow to recall vehicles with faulty rearview cameras, and it failed to give the agency complete information, which is required by the Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Act.

raw.headline: Ford agrees to pay up to $165 million penalty to US government for moving too slowly on a recall
raw.summary: Ford Motor Co. will pay a penalty of up to $165 million to the U.S. government for moving too slowly on a recall and failing to give accurate recall information.  The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Thursday that the civil penalty is the second-largest in its 54-year history.  The agency said Ford was too slow to recall vehicles with faulty rearview cameras, and it failed to give the agency complete information, which is required by the Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Act.

headline: Ford Motor hit with $165 million US penalty over delayed rearview camera recalls
summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Thursday Ford Motor has agreed to a $165 million civil penalty after a government investigation found the automaker failed to recall vehicles with defective rearview cameras in a timely manner.  Under a consent order that will last at least three years, the No. 2 U.S. automaker must pay $65 million in cash, spend $45 million on advanced data analytics, a new testing facility and other projects and $55 million will be held in abeyance subject to complying with the agreement.  NHTSA in August 2021 opened an investigation after Ford in 2020 recalled 620,246 vehicles for a rear camera issue to determine whether the carmaker recalled the vehicles in a timely fashion.

raw.headline: Ford Motor hit with $165 million US penalty over delayed rearview camera recalls

Under a consent order that will last at least three years, the No. 2 U.S. automaker must pay $65 million in cash, spend $45 million on advanced data analytics, a new testing facility and other projects and $55 million will be held in abeyance subject to complying with the agreement.  NHTSA in August 2021 opened an investigation after Ford in 2020 recalled 620,246 vehicles for a rear camera issue to determine whether the carmaker recalled the vehicles in a timely fashion.
